Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research LTREB: Understanding the strength, duration, and stability of connectivity effects on community diversity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Habitat loss is the greatest cause of biodiversity loss, as it isolates small patches of habitat along with the populations in these fragments. This project examines landscape connectivity, which is the inverse of fragmentation, and the degree to which corridors among fragments facilitate the movement of organisms and thus alleviate the effects of fragmentation. Although habitat connectivity is considered to be fundamental to the maintenance of species diversity, there is remarkably little empirical evidence documenting the effects of corridors. The investigators will extend an ongoing experiment explicitly designed to test the effects of habitat connectivity. Results to date show that species diversity increases when fragments are connected by corridors, but the question remains whether these responses are short-term or persistent. The project will generate long-term data to resolve the mechanisms underlying the relationship between connectivity, diversity, and time, and to determine whether connectivity effects are long-lasting or transient.


This experiment provides a direct link to conservation by manipulating connectivity through landscape corridors. Strategies to reconnect landscapes through landscape corridors have dominated land acquisitions in conservation. Results of this project will provide some of the first evidence for land managers of the value of landscape connections for protecting biological diversity. The project will develop a solutions-oriented workshop with scientists and land managers to catalyze the translation of science to practical long-term land conservation in the southeastern United States study region. A website dedicated to bridging the science and practice of conservation corridors will contribute to these efforts. Both graduate and undergraduate students will be engaged in and trained through participation in the research, continuing a successful collaboration with the US Forest Service to train and mentor women and students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People have converted many forest, grassland, and wetland landscapes to farm fields and urban areas. This has caused loss of habitat area available to plants and animals. In addition to reduced area, the natural habitat that remains has been chopped into smaller and smaller fragments, for example in the form of woodlots or city parks that are widely dispersed across landscapes. How do we conserve biodiversity and functioning ecosystems in these landscapes?

One strategy used to restore native species to landscapes is to conserve habitats that reconnect the small fragments that remain. When natural areas are fragmented, farm fields or urban areas may create barriers to plants or animals that may want to move to other places. If they venture out of their native habitats, they may be entering dangerous territory where they are more likely to perish. So-called landscape corridors serve as highways for plants and animals to move safely between areas of habitat. If corridors work as intended, more movement across the landscape will serve to increase population sizes and biodiversity in connected landscapes. However, it is unknown whether corridors work in this way.

This project, conducted in the largest landscape experiment dedicated to the study of corridors, showed that corridors do indeed increase plant diversity. Fragments in connected landscapes had an astounding 24 more plant species, bringing the total number of plant species in each connected fragment up to two hundred.

An important aspect of this project is its long duration. The experimental landscapes have been in place for over two decades. This has led to the unprecedented conclusion that the effects of corridors are durable, increasing plant diversity over that entire time period. Furthermore, the number of species in connected fragments has been increasing for the entire time period, and the difference is not yet leveling off. A study of even longer duration is required to understand the full effects of landscape corridors.

The long-term nature of this study permitted understanding of the factors that caused higher diversity. As expected, corridors were indeed highways for plants, increasing their ability to colonize connected patches. Corridors also decreased extinction rates, likely because higher dispersal added individuals to populations and helped to prevent population declines to extinction. The effects on colonization and extinction rates were durable over the entire study, and further emphasized the need for long-term research.

Corridors do not only affect plants, they affect entire ecological systems. For example, corridors increased the dispersal of animals including bees and flies. These species serve as prey for green lynx spiders that feed on pollinators at flowers. Through a novel tracking method, one study found that corridors increased the spread of prey, and thus increased spider body condition in connected patches.

The results of this study have broad impacts that extend to managed landscapes across the world. As part of this study, a survey of conservation practitioners showed that habitat loss and fragmentation is of highest concern, and that re-connecting landscapes is the preferred conservation strategy. This project produced the website ConservationCorridor.com to translate science to managers. The website now reaches over 40,000 per year.
